definition:

capable of giving a sensation of heat or of burning, searing, or scalding

having heat in a degree exceeding normal body heat                                      
             
             Your forehead feels hot.

marked by violence or fierceness : stormy                                      
             
             a hot temper

sexually excited or receptive

sexy

emotionally exciting and marked by strong rhythms and free melodic improvisations

having or causing the sensation of an uncomfortable degree of body heat                                      
             
             hot and tired

newly made : fresh                                      
             
             a hot scent

close to something sought                                      
             
             hot on the trail

suggestive of heat or of burning or glowing objects : very bright                                      
             
             hot colors

pungent, peppery                                      
             
             hot mustard

of intense and immediate interest

unusually lucky or favorable

             a hot idea

absurd, unbelievable

wanted by the police

fast

hotly

fast, quickly

one that is hot (such as a hot meal or a horse just after a workout)

strong sexual desire

heat, warm

working outside in the hot sun

the hottest chili I've ever tasted

a hot item in stores this year
wants to fight the champ? that's a hot one
admitted that the car was hot
made the town too hot for them
a hot lap around the track
during the hot of the day
has got the hots for the new guy in the office
I asked the waitress to hot up another slice of pie.
It is hot in the summer and cold in the winter.
The baked potatoes were too hot to handle with our bare hands.

definition: very high in temperature
feeling uncomfortable because the temperature is too high or you are wearing too many clothes
used about the weather
where the weather is often hot
cooked and served hot
hot food contains a lot of spices that create a burning feeling in your mouth
involving strong emotions
a hot issue is important and causes arguments because people strongly disagree
exciting and interesting, especially because of being new
exciting, successful, and popular
especially good in some way
very skilful
very lucky
difficult, or dangerous
involving sexual feelings or images
sexually attractive
keen to have sex
determined to do something
involving a lot of activity or competition
stolen and being looked for by the police
used in a children’s game for saying that you are very close to finding something, or to guessing the right answer
in: Cook the fish under a hot grill for 5 minutes.
Her forehead still feels a bit hot.
It’s so hot in here – can’t we open a window?
boiling/scalding hot  (=extremely hot): a pan of boiling hot water
Take your jacket off if you’re hot.
It’s going to be hot again today.
The disease is particularly common in hot countries such as India and Panama.
I haven’t had a hot meal in days.
have a hot temper  (=get angry easily): Our coach has a really hot temper.
Tax cuts have become a hot topic in this election campaign.
hot news about impending changes in Cabinet
the hot new look in women’s fashions
one of Hollywood’s hottest young directors
a hot property  (=someone in acting, sport, business etc who has just become very successful): She’s now a very hot property in television.
a hot tip  (=a useful piece of advice)
hot at: Kyle’s pretty hot at tennis.
hot for: When things got too hot for her at home, she’d stay with a friend.
love scenes that are too hot for TV
hot for: Hot for revenge, the soldiers marched northward.
The property market is very hot these days.
hot competition: There is hot competition from other companies to win the contract.

definition: having a high temperature:
used to describe food that causes a burning feeling in the mouth:
used to describe a subject that causes a lot of disagreement or discussion:
new and exciting:
knowing a lot or skilful:
an accurate piece of advice about who will win a race:
the person or animal that is most likely to win a race, competition, election, etc.:
to think that a particular thing is very important and to demand that it is done well or correctly:
Hot goods have been recently stolen and are therefore difficult to sell or dangerous to deal with because the police are still looking for them.
sexually attractive, or feeling sexually excited:
If someone has a hot temper, they are easily made angry.
(of food) causing a feeling in the mouth like burning or tingling (= as if a lot of sharp points are being put in quickly and lightly):
easily excited, or angry:
very good and having energy:
(of goods) stolen and therefore difficult to sell:
(of a situation) dangerous or difficult; risky:
physically attractive
in: It's too hot in here, can we turn down the heating?
Bake the cake in a hot oven, about 220°C, for 30 minutes.
The food was piping hot (= very hot).
Global warming has become a very hot issue.
This 21-year-old actor has become Hollywood's hottest property.
I'm not too hot on Russian history.
Do you have any hot tips for this afternoon's race?
He's the hot favourite to win the election.
They're very hot on dress at work so she always looks very smart for the office.
I've got a hot date tonight.
It’s hotter in Ohio than it is here.
Matt makes his little sister hot chocolate (= a warm drink made with chocolate).
If you like curry really hot, you can add some hot peppers and hot sauce.
I got really hot about them not recycling.
Right now the stock market is hot.
Those CD players are so cheap, they must be hot.
Things got a lot hotter when the military took over.
